page.lettertext:
fol.288r
1592 4 Septem
b
To my L. Trea
s
May it please your good L. I receaved
e last of Au
g
at night, by
e post
of
Lond
o
, her
M
t
l
re
of
e 22 of
e same moneth, and one from your L. of
e
21. The 2 of Sep
t
I proposed to
e
States
e points of my charge: w
ch
they re
q
red after of me, and I delivered them in writing: whereof heereinclo-
sed I have sent you
e transcript. In our conference together they re
q
sted
me solemnly, as I tendered
e good estate of her M
tie
and
e c
o
trey,
at I would
signify plainly to them, whether her Hig
nes
c
o
mandm
e
t for embarking
e c
o
panies
were directed unto me in suche
emptorie sort,
at it might not be delayed
for a litle longer time. Whereto in mine awnswear I praied them
to thinke,
at there was not any meanes, to differ
e time in their behalf.
They might allwayes
ceave it by her owne often writing, and by the
effect of those messages
at I had delivered: w
ch
were to signify
at purpose
w
ch
is re
q
red at this p
nt
to be put in execution. And so I desired
at they
would understand it, and take some order out of hand, wherby her
M
tie
and
e co
u
trey might be served w
t
c
o
tent. And for their further
assurance of her full determination, I offered them to reade
e l
re
s
e
t unto me. They would not seeme to put in doubt
e trueth
of my speache, and therefore sought not to see w
at
was written unto
me: but being greatly dismaied went p
nt
ly aside, and after communic
a
on
had among themselves, they declared unto me,
at if
e state of their
army were knowen to her M
tie
considering how much it importeth
her self, they were sure she would be moved to have her people imployed
for
e time of
e siedge. For
e Castel of
Coevoerden
was greatly
distressed, and
e Enemy to relieve it had assembled all his strengthe
and was encamped close unto it. If
e Englishe were w
t
drawen, and
at supplie that was re
q
red for
e garrison of
Berghen
, they should ether
be c
o
strained to dissolve their army p
nt
ly, or by severing of their forces
runne in danger of
e ruine both of them and all
e reste. Besides
it would discredit
e course of all their actions, and give occasion
of murmur to
e c
o
mons of
e c
o
trey, who had yelded this s
o
mer to a
great deale greater c
o
tribution, for an extraordinary Levie, then they
had ever done before, amounting at
e lest to six score thousand
poundes sterling: w
ch
would all be cast away, and
e people discouraged
to doe
e like hereafter. And where it might be supposed,
at their army all together, surmounting every way
e n
o
bers of
e Enemy,
might make a good retraite, it was
at w
ch
they doubted most. For the
Enemies c
o
manders were much to be respected, as men more sufficient,
and of greater ex
ience, then
Count Maurice
had any. For defence
fol.288v
of a sconce or of a towne and for besieging of a place and maintening
a skermishe, they were well
suaded of their service: but they thought
them farre unable to marche awaye in
fit sort, w
t
out geving to the
Enemy any special adv
a
tage, and to range themselves in
at order, as
if
e Enemy should determine to bidde them battel up
o
e waye, they might
answear it in skill as well as in courage. For these occasions they
p
tended
at
e l
re
s of her M
tie
were wholy out of season, and therefore earnestly intrea-
ted,
at I would staye
e public
a
on of
e pleasure of her Hig
nes
and not certifie
S
r
Francis Vere
, till they saw a little further, w
at
e Enemy would attempt.
I had not much to reply, in respect of those dangers,
at they alleaged might
ensue: but I declared unto them,
at they were allwayes heretofore, to
p
sume
at the Enemy would rescue e place: and before
at
e siege was begunne
by Co
u
t Maurice, they had knowledge fr
o
her Hig
nes
that she would sende
for
e c
o
panies:
at if any inc
o
veni
e
ce shall followe therup
o
, by their c
o
ming
from
e campe, they should blame themselves and not her M
tie
who could
no longer forslowe
e assisting of
e
King
, aswell for her
mise as
for
e urg
e
t necessitie wherunto he was reduced, and they had reason to
regard no lesse th
e
herselfe. What her M
tie
would resolve, if she
knoweth their p
nt
state and heard their alleg
a
ons, I could not well c
o
je-
cture, but for mine owne particular, it was not left unto me, to doe as
I would, and therefore prayed their assist
a
ce to
e acc
o
plishing of my charges.
They knewe S
r
Francis Vere was well affected to this c
o
trey: he was nowe
at
e c
a
pe, and could judge by being p
nt
, if his troupes might be spared,
w
t
out their
p
judice. For if any such mater were appar
a
t
u
to him,
he would not be so wilfull, as to leave them in extremitie, w
ch
he was
sure would not stande w
t
her M
ts
good liking. The mater thu[s]
debated w
t
speeches to and fro, when they sawe I would not yelde, not [to]
signify to S
r
Francis her Hig
nes
intent,
e whole assemblie was inst
a
t w
t
[me]
to refraine fr
o
sending to him, for no more but 2 dayes longer: whe[rewith]
they thought they might be steeded, for
at
e Enemy was so neere, and [had]
a purpose, as it seemed, and as Coevoerden re
q
red, to essay o
r
forces [to the]
uttermost. Their importunitie was so great, as to so s[mall a]
d
e
mande, w
ch
I hoped would not hinder her M
ties
designes, and I
ceave[d might]
availe to satisfy their mindes, I was c
o
tented to assent and
mise [not to]
write, till
at 2 dayes were ex
red, to S
r
Francis Vere, wherw
t
her M
tie
, [I trust]
will be nothing displeased, if your L. will vouchsafe, to thinke
e [best]
of my
ceeding. We had intellig
e
ce to day, w
ch
is
e se[cond of]
e two, that they desired at my handes,
at Coevoerden had c
o
pounde[d whereof]
I have written this morning unto you, by a fitt opportunitie, w
ch
wa[s offred]
fol.289r
me to send by one that w
e
t for
Zeland
. I have bin also w
t
e
States
,
to hasten their answear to her M
ts
demaundes, and expecially to
at w
ch
c
o
cerned
e c
o
panies, declaring plainely to them,
at I was minded this
evening to dispatche unto S
r
Francis. They signify thereup
o
that
they will p
nt
ly resolve, and will sett it downe in writing aswell for
at mater as for
e rest
at I proposed, c
o
cerning
Britaine
,
Ostend
, and
e
18 c
a
noniers, and send it me to day, or to morowe at
e furthest. Which
when I have receaved I will joine w
t
this l
re
and send it to your L.
But if they happen to delay me, I will send away this l
re
and c
o
veye
their answear when it cometh. Which I doe make a full accounte
about
e mater of
e c
o
panies, will be altogether negative. And yet
as farre as I
ceave, by the maner of their dealing and by
e opinion
of others, they will not lette their passage. Howsoever they doe
determine, I will
right
write
this night to S
r
Francis Vere and send the copies
of those l
re
s,
at I have receaved, and
e l
re
unto him from my
LL.
of
e Councell: w
ch
will cause him, I am sure, to come away fourthwith:
and as soon as he is come,
e directions sent unto us from my LL.
e 1
of July last, shall be followed very thorowly. I have
moved
M
r
Caron
, as your L. hath willed, to assiste me in my suite,
to have
e Companies away, w
t
e liking of
e c
o
trey. He wanteth
no good will, to doe his best in that behalf, but no doubt it is so, as he
himself doth affirme, that it is not for him w
t
this people, to make
at
motion for her M
tie
. For considering their bent, he shall but purchasse
an opinion of partiallitie in his dealing, and
p
vaile by no
suasion.
I can not learne by any meanes, to report upon knowledge, for w
at
occ
a
on
he was sent for. To my understanding
at w
ch
he doth
p
tend, about
his privat estate is farre from
e mater. For I am still of
at opinion
as when I writte to your L.
e 20 of
e last. Of
e strength
of
e c
o
panies,
at are w
t
S
r
Francis, as I have formerly advertised,
e
rolles were c
o
signed, about
e 10 day of Au
g
to
e handes of
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
,
e musters being taken
e 8 and 15 of July. I have sent heereinclo-
sed the Abbreviat of them: having taken further order,
at
M
r
Allen
e Commissary shall p
nt
ly call a muster, when S
r
Francis is returned.
Fr
o
e Campe we heare no more, but
at
e 2 of this moneth,
Verdugo
w
t
his forces being fast by
e Castel, it was surrendred to Count Maurice,
having made their c
o
position, to depart w
t
bagge and baggage, and enseignes
[disployed]. There were saide to marche away about
e n
o
ber of 500.
It is advertised fr
o
neutral places,
at are neere unto
e Enemy,
at in the
attempt which they gave
e 28 of
e last, to enter our trenches, there
fol.289v
were at
e lest 400 slaine, and were all recovered by
e Enemy, and
carried away, unles it were a 100 w
ch
were killed in
e trenches.
Of ours there was one man onely slaine, and six others hurt, of w
ch
Count William
was one being shotte a thwart
e belly, but w
t
out a[ny]
danger. Wheras we have bin told,
at
Count Charles Mansfield
and
Mondragon
were there in
son, it seemeth by
e occurrences, w
ch
come from neutrall places,
at they are not w
t
Verdugo.
And thus
I take my humble leave. At
e Hage Sep
t
4 1592.
